Dear Mr. Gonzalez:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
July 13, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In the
event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact the
area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee Records
(1) An institution shall maintain employee
records for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule.
(i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the equivalent
state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the
person usually resides, that the person has
not been determined to be a perpetrator of
2

child abuse or child neglect. The
documentation shall be completed not more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment
and every 12 months thereafter.
Two of sixteen new employee files had a central registry clearance completed
more than 30 days prior to the employee’s hire date. One employee was hired
4/12/23, but the central registry check was completed on 3/9/23. A second
employee was hired 4/18/23, but the central registry check was completed on
3/17/23.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers.
(1) The licensee shall document, prior to
employment, that each employee and
volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2
consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1 year
period before employment and shall be
verified every 1 year after the last verification
or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
Four of sixteen new employee files did not contain verification of a negative
tuberculosis test prior to hire. Two staff members completed tests, but never
went back to have the test results read so it is unknown if they were negative.
A third staff does not have a TB test on file at all. A fourth staff cancelled his TB
testing appointment and there is not a test or result in the employee’s file.
CCI Rule 400.4145 Periodic physical examinations
(1) An institution shall provide and document
periodic physical examination for each
resident as follows, unless greater frequency
is medically indicated.
(b) At least once every 14 months for residents
1 year of age or older.
One of six active youth files reviewed did not have an annual physical in the
file.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign,
and date an initial treatment plan for each
resident within 30 calendar days of admission.

CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge Plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from
institutional care, all of the following
information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and
the new location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of
the services provided while in residence,
including medical and dental services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that
remain to be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the
facility after discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and
dental follow up that is needed, have been
4

reviewed with the resident and with the
parent and the responsible case manager.
(f) The name and the official title of the person
to whom the resident was discharged.
One of two closed youth files reviewed did not have a discharge summary
outlining subsections (a)-(f) in the file. The summary was later provided upon
request.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Provided the facility with the TB Variance information again to ensure the
requirements of the variance are complied with.
• Provided the facility with a reminder of Rule 400.4115 regarding CPR/First
Aid training to ensure the facility is scheduling staff on shift accordingly.
• The clothing inventories for Ridgeview youth need to be kept in youth files
(initials and discharge).
• One open youth file did not contain a dental exam completed within 12
months prior or 90 days after admission. The youth's dental exam was
completed 6/3/22 & his admission date was 2/24/22. This dental was due
prior to the timeframes of this audit, so it does not count as a violation.
However, the agency needs to make sure medical and dental exam
documentation for 12 months prior to admission follows the youth's file to
each CCI within Bethany Christian Services.
• The facility should not delay putting a discharge summary into the youth's
file while waiting for the new case management team to sign it. As long as
the current case manager and case management supervisor sign, that is
sufficient.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The quarterly file reviews aren't occuring for youth in TLC. The file review
form is in each of the youth files, but no one is signing off or dating they've
completed the quarterly review. Although this isn't a licensing requirement,
it is part of the facility's process and should be followed to ensure an
accurate and complete file for the youth.
• Face sheets for files aren't being completed for TLC youth files. Although
this isn't a licensing requirement, it is part of the facility's process and
should be followed to ensure an accurate and complete file for the youth.
• The Closing file review for discharged TLC youth wasn't done per the file
review signature page. The youth discharged in September 2022. Although
this isn't a licensing requirement, it is part of the facility's process and
should be followed to ensure an accurate and complete file for the youth.
5

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility had two special investigations during this period under review. One
investigation (2023C0000016) resulted in a corrective action plan, but the other
investigation (2023C0000557) is ongoing. The corrective action plan for SI
2023C0000016 dated 1/25/23 addressed rule violations for 4109(1)(c) Program
Statement and 4132(4) Grievance Procedures. The facility updated their cell phone
policy to reflect how staff are to use their personal cell phones at work. In addition,
the facility updated their grievances policy and procedure as well as created a
grievance tracking form. Since implementing the CAP, the facility has been
successful in training staff on the new cell phone policy, supervision of youth has
improved and the overall culture on the units has improved. The facility has been
successful in ongoing implementation and monitoring of their CAP and provides the
appropriate documentation when requested.
Financial Overview
The facility's 2023 financial budget and Bethany Christian Services' 2022 financial
audit were reviewed. There were no concerns noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
The MDHHS Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA) compliance monitoring report
was completed on 12/15/22 and the facility was found in compliance with all
standards.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted Bethany Christian Services Residential program
has been in licensing and contract compliance, but there are two systemic factors
that have an impact on keeping all youth safe and providing the best treatment for
them. The first is the lack of alternative placements for youth whose behavior
warrants placement in a different level-of-care setting and the second is continued
staffing issues. As with most residential facilities, the wages and hours have had a
significant impact on staffing. CA reported they continued to partner with Human
Resources to design engaging job postings, advocate for a review of youth
specialist wages, partner with current staff to recruit staff from their network and
continue to offer recruitment incentives for current staff to recruit friends in their
network to work for Bethany. CA noted there was one corrective action plan (CAP)
implemented over the last year in relation to a special investigation. CA reported
6

the updated policies as a result of the CAP have had a positive impact. Staff are
aware of the updated cell phone policy and are not being distracted from
supervising youth. In addition, grievances are now being tracked and none have
been lost or unaddressed.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported there is good communication when there are changes,
policy updates, incidents, etc. Staff reported being short staffed has been difficult at
times, but they know the facility is consistently trying to improve staffing by
interviewing and hiring. A couple staff reported they feel there could be more
consistency between Ridgeview-East and Ridgeview-West because staff
sometimes work on different units. Staff feel they are supported, can bring up
concerns when needed and will be heard regarding those concerns. Staff feel
compensation can always be improved due to the rising costs of living, but they like
their jobs and that's why they stay employed with Bethany.
Three youth from Ridgeview and two youth from TLC were interviewed on 6/28/23.
The youth from Ridgeview did not have any concerns. They reported they felt safe
at the facility, feel they have a voice, feel staff listen to them, feel staff care about
them, and they feel staff do everything possible to intervene during situations that
arise. The two youth from TLC stated they feel safe at the facility and have no
concerns with interactions with staff. Both youths stated they would like to have
more access to WiFi to make calls due to the differences in time zones between
Michigan and where their families reside. They also stated they used to have
weekly house meetings but feel the meetings have been less consistent lately.
They want to have consistent house meetings to ensure their voices are heard. The
youth also stated they want to have more outings and outdoor activities since it is
summer.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour of the facility occurred during the inspection on 6/28/23. The facility was
clean and in good condition. There were no safety concerns noted during the
inspection.
7

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
